metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[Page One]
Fort Hill
2nd May 1845
My dear sir,
In answer to your first enquiry, 
as to the prohibiting of a war with England and others
is, one or both, I am of the opinion, there is 
but little danger of one with the latter, when
she should be backed by the former; and that 
is not probable, unless England should con-
clude, that a rupture between us and her is 
probable from the Oregon questions. I am 
of the impression, that all danger of hostility
is from that question. Indeed, I was so strong[?] in-
proped[?] with that opinion that I deemed it
my duty to give Mr. Polk and Mr. Buchanan, 
a full statement of the state of the negotiations; 
my impression of the mode in which the nego-
tiation ought to be conducted, in order to avoid
hostilities, and effect, at the same time, can [illegible]; 
and the great danger of being involved in hostil-
ities with England and of losing the [illegible], unless
the questions should be managed with 
great delicacy[?], combined with great finess
[Page Two]
and address. I also stated my opinion, that the quiet and even
careful termination of the Zenian[?] question depended 
much on the Oregon; that England had no ground
on which she could stand to come to a negative
with us, in reference to the former, and that if she 
intended to give us any trouble about it, she 
would make Oregon the pretense, unless it was 
so mingled as to preach it. I, in addition, 
emphatically stated, that the joint occupancy[?] 
was the key of the Oregon question; think if we 
held on to it and conducted the questions, as it ought 
to be, it was hardly possible we could fail; 
but, if we decided, it would be very difficult 
to avoid hostilities and the Cap [captain] of the territory. I acted
on that belief throughout, and it was owing to 
my efforts and influence, that the solution to re-
cede did not pass in the last [illegible].
My conversation[?] with Mr. Polk [took place] on my first in-
terview with him, and long before his inaugural 
was prepared, as I suffered. It was intended 
to guard him. When I saw it, and saw how daring
he had gone against my views, I said at once 
to some of his friends, that I much regretted it, 
and that the course he had taken, would 
[Page Three]
give such trouble; endanger the peace of the country, 
and, not improbably, the loss of the Treaty[?].
You will see from all this, that, I think, there
is much danger. Mr. Polk, Mr. Buchanan, Mr. 
Walker and Mr. Johnson are openly committed to 
the party of receding the joint occupancy, and [today?]
stopping of the Treaty[?]. If that is done, hostilities 
are inevitable. I fear they will neither have
the patriotism nor makings to change their grounds[?]
and, if that should be so, every thing will depend on
the Senate and the South to arrest so mad a conman. 
I call it mad, for it is something worse than 
folly. If they do their [duty?], [peace?] may still be 
[present?]. England does not desire war. On 
the contrary, she [dreads?] its efforts, and wishes for 
peace. I cannot but think, it will yet be [needed?], 
but there is much danger. 
The probability is, that there will be much agi-
tation of the question of peace or war at the next
[Zenian?], by the administration should intrest
and settle the [Oregon] question by being the boundary between the [two]
counties in the way. The difficulty of doing that has 
been much increased by the greater intrest on 
the inaugural and the late debate in Parliament; 
which may still be done, I think, if Mr. 
[Page Four]
Buchanan should have the venue to settle in. I believe
him to be inclined to do so, but I doubt his [friendship?]. 
As to the efforts of the war, if it should occur, 
I cannot doubt, but it will be [calamitous?] to 
both countries, and especially so to our banking
institutions. It would be difficult for them 
to avoid [suspicion?] either South or North.
For now have my opinion. I do not intend 
it for the publick, but have no [objection?] to it 
being made known to such friends, or you may
think proper, and in chore [direction?] you can 
[illegible]. 
Yours truly
J.[John] C.[Caldwell] Calhoun
H.[Henry] W.[Workman] Conner Sr.
